results.title: Halloween
results.creator_credit: Falcon Film, Debra Hill and John Carpenter
results.brief_description: John Carpenter’s much imitated ‘Halloween’ defined the eighties stalk and slash genre, spawning inferior copies like the ‘Friday the 13th’ series (including six sequels of it’s own), and for a time making star Jamie Lee Curtis into the premium “scream queen”. Later on the conventions of the genre were cleverly re-invented for a nineties audience by director Wes Craven and writer Kevin Williamson in ‘Scream’, which pays direct homage to ‘Halloween’. John Carpenter opens his film with an unnerving point of view shot of the young psychotic Michael Myers brutally stabbing his teenage sister to death on Halloween night. Flash forward to Halloween 15 years later and Michael has escaped the mental institution he has been locked up in. Meanwhile shy, virginal teenager Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) and her girlfriends are preparing for Halloween, unaware of the menace that lurks in their quiet suburban community. Carpenter makes great use of the sparse, atmospheric music score (which he also composed), and uses to maximum creepy effect the white mask Michael Myers wears throughout the film. The film also established the classic horror genre rule- if your a sexually active teenager, you die! Cast also includes Donald Pleasence, P.J. Soles, Tony Moran.

results.title: Hallo: communications in a nutshell
results.creator_credit: Unesco, Bucharest Studios and Jehangir Bhownagary
results.brief_description: An animated cartoon film giving a brief popular outline of the history of communications from signal drums to satellite relaying. No commentary - music by Dumitru Capoianu.
results.description: An animated cartoon film giving a brief popular outline of the history of communications from signal drums to satellite relaying. No commentary - music by Dumitru Capoianu.

results.title: Hallmarking
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Myer Productions, Goldsmith's Company of London, Jack Holmes and Andrew Holmes
results.brief_description: Traces the history of hall-marking and the evolution of different marks. Hall-marks represent a guarantee of quality and are based on stringent tests. Shows modern gold and silverware being tested at the London Assay Office. The different stages in the analysis are seen in detail.

results.title: Halley
results.creator_credit: York Films of England and Terence Murtagh
results.brief_description: Provides a historical look at Halley’s Comet; considers work of Halley; notes popularity of comet watching in eighteenth and nineteenth century and briefly shows how NASA space vehicle “Giotto” will rendezvous with Halley’s comet in 1986.

results.title: Hallelujah Darwin!
results.creator_credit: Magic Lantern, Robert Brandreth-Gibbs and Kip Cates
results.brief_description: The biography of Charles Darwin is told using animated characters. His educational and religious background is followed by his voyage with reasons for the development of his theory of natural selection.

results.title: Halfbrick wall
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Brickwork”.
Shows method for constructing a halfbrick wall including the first stage of constructing the corners; use of stretcher bond; the importance of checking with plumb level; the correct method of laying bricks, use of line and pins and corner blocks.

results.title: Half of mankind
results.creator_credit: Films Division, Government of India, United Nations and Ezra Mir
results.brief_description: This film deals with community development in Asia. The village is the unit of organization on which Asia rests, and it is the basis of community development. Three examples are shown: simple self-help in Cambodia; villages cooperating with the World Health Organization to run a health clinic in Afghanistan; interdependence of the agricultural and industrial communities in India, with cash crops providing capital for agricultural development and mechanized expansion of village crafts with the aid of electricity.

results.title: Half life
results.brief_description: Filmed in an abandoned silo in Collingwood and featuring the haunting vocals of Wendy Rule, this music video examines a woman trapped by her own depression. Nominated for an ATOM Award.
